postsData.content:
A common complaint that I've heard about coaching programs: 

They're not long enough!

A lot of coaches run three month programs, and although 90 days sounds like a long time, it flies by quickly. Halloween was three months ago, that doesn't seem that long ago does it?

And some coaches do six month programs, but they go by quickly too and can leave loose ends when they finish.

That's why when I was planning my new Natural Born Coaches Program I decided to make it open-ended, meaning that the coaches who join can stay in as long as the program is running.

That means they get access to all of the programs in it, including new ones launched down the road, and continuing access to the group support calls (even if it's way down the road).

And those who join in the initial launch also get 6 monthly 1:1 calls with me to help their progress.

Interested? The next step is to book a call to chat about it at the link in the comments!

comments.commentText: www.nbcprogram.com

postsData.commentAdded: Love the open-ended approach! Continuous access and support can truly make a difference in coaching. Excited to see how this evolves! üåü

postsData.content:
The "dog ate my homework" has been replaced by "AI did my homework". 
The teachers that demand that students are NOT allowed to use LLMs are shooting their students in the foot. One of my kids had to sign an integrity letter promising they would not use LLMs for school. Dumb. The education system has to change, teaching kids in pre-LLM is equivalent to the stone age for what they need for their future.

Is it cheating? No, not with the right system. The grade curve has shifted, some of you were disliked in school because you ruined the curve. AI is 'ruining the curve'. Imagine a distribution of grade for an essay, written by humans. Now imagine the distribution scored by a naive teacher who doesn't understand AI, the reports all got better and shifted to the right.

For the lazy students, the procrastinators their position in the curve hasn't changed. If you forgot about your report the night before and right before bed you have an LLM right it... if you're computing/competing against humans you might get a high score 95%. If you're competing against humans using AI, you will get a low score, 60%.

Compare the procrastinator to the student who spent the same amount of time as they might normally spend, 3-5 hours, doing a report. They are doing multiple iterations, their prompting is getting better, their research is going wider, their style is being perfected. They are delivering a paper that in the human world might have received the highest school for the entire district.

Stop holding our kids back, stop preparing them for the present when you should be preparing them for the future.

The main issue is access, kids with access to more expensive LLMs will have an unfair advantage to those who do not. The education system and governments should figure out how to enable all students with great LLM access.

comments.commentText:
I agree with the accessibility and the inclusivity for all then we really would have a 'free world' 
Where everyone has access to clean water, sanitary products, food, shelter and healthcare.

One thing I am curious to discuss with more people is, how do we enable children to have more time to ‚ÄúThink Deeper‚Äù? 

Their 3-5 hours of investment in improving their craft in that report, can shift from data gatehering and source validation to data processing, and increased repetition & application, and decision making.

Improved group discussions and conversations, time spent storytelling and conveying their point of view, while learning other people‚Äôs points of view. Ultimately, solving for problems empowered by data driven insights we didn‚Äôt have growing up.

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely! Embracing AI in education can elevate learning if we adapt our systems. Let‚Äôs prepare students for a tech-driven future! üåü

postsData.content:
'Always on' hustle culture isn't success.
It's a recipe for burnout.

Here are 7 research-backed signs you're heading for burnout:

1. Decision Paralysis
‚Ü≥ You struggle with simple choices
‚Ü≥ Create decision-making frameworks for recurring choices

2. Decreased Performance
‚Ü≥ You take longer to complete routine tasks
‚Ü≥ Prioritize tasks based on energy levels, not just deadlines

3. Memory Loss & Brain Fog
‚Ü≥ You struggle with simple tasks you once mastered
‚Ü≥ Block focused time for complex tasks when your energy peaks

4. Emotional Exhaustion
‚Ü≥ You lose passion for work you once loved
‚Ü≥ Create clear start and end times for your workday

5. Physical Warning Signs
‚Ü≥ You experience unexplained headaches and tension
‚Ü≥ Schedule regular movement breaks between meetings

6. Social Withdrawal
‚Ü≥ You avoid team interactions
‚Ü≥ Build regular check-ins with trusted colleagues

7. Cynicism Creep
‚Ü≥ You become unusually critical of others
‚Ü≥ Document wins and positive feedback for perspective


Success isn't about being always available.

It‚Äôs about building a sustainable way of working.

postsData.content:
A common sentence is: "I regret not having fired an employee quickly enough."

However, before I decide to terminate someone, I always consider these points:

1. The reasons for a dismissal are not always clear-cut. Often, it is a matter of judgment that can impact the entire team.

During the 2014 World Cup, Kevin Gro√ükreutz was mocked for becoming a world champion without playing a single minute. But those who were in the locker room knew how important he was for team cohesion. Just like in a sports team, individual performance is not the only thing that matter, the dynamics and overall performance of a team or department also play a crucial role.

Sometimes, a person who is not a top performer still contributes positively to group dynamics. However, if someone consistently falls short of expectations, it can affect the motivation of the entire team.

2. People at the beginning of their careers deserve a second chance. Especially with young professionals, it often turns out that they are better suited for a different role. In my company, I have frequently seen cases where someone was initially hired for a specific position but, after a short time, thrived and was much more successful in a different area.

3. The key question at the end of the probation period.
When the probation period is about to end, I always ask myself:

"Knowing what I know today, would I hire this person again?"

comments.commentText: Love this Cristian Mudure. One more thing to consider: Is the issue skill or mindset? Skills can be developed, but if someone lacks accountability or a growth mentality, no amount of coaching will fix it.

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Balancing performance and team dynamics is crucial. Giving young professionals a second chance can lead to unexpected successes!

The rules we are taught to follow:

Don't be disruptive.
Stay humble, avoid attention.
Follow the traditional path.
Wait your turn.
Don't ask for too much.
Play it safe.

I know these rules all too well. 

Yet look at the most successful people and brands in the world ‚Äì they break every one of these rules.

The disruptors reshape industries. The delegators build empires. The attention-seekers become influencers. The best salespeople change the world. The rule-breakers create new industries. The impatient innovate faster. The bold negotiators earn more. And those who take calculated risks? They're the ones making history.

Sometimes extraordinary success means unlearning what we've been taught.
I learned that through nearly two decades working for Martha Stewart. It was like getting my MBA in personal branding with Professor Stewart; failing wasn't an option.

I learned that excellence isn't just a goal ‚Äì it's a daily practice.

Listen to the 7 Lessons I learned at Martha University. A good reminder that breaking the rules is a path that's never crowded.
_______________
Ready to build a personal brand that breaks through the noise? My Sunday Sunshine readers tell me: your personal brand isn't just important ‚Äì it's everything.

If you're a high achiever ready to:
-Turn industry rules into opportunities
-Transform your expertise into undeniable influence
-Build a brand that opens doors before you even walk in

High level summary of Q4 2024 in the Austin Office Market. (Full Report Attached)

Economic Strength: Austin's economy remains robust, adding 22,000 jobs YOY with a low unemployment rate of 3.5%, outperforming both state (4.2%) and national averages.

High Vacancy Rates: The overall office vacancy rate increased to 29.8%, with the Central Business District (CBD) reaching 30.0%. A surplus of new speculative office buildings has contributed significantly to elevated vacancy levels.

Leasing Activity Improvement: Despite economic uncertainty, Q4 2024 ended positively with 884,000 square feet leased, contributing to a modest yearly net absorption of 259,000 square feet. However, the CBD recorded a negative absorption of 269,000 square feet.

Stable Pricing: Asking rents have remained stable despite elevated vacancies, with the average market rate at $47.45 per square foot. Class A spaces in the CBD lead the market at $65.63 per square foot.

Construction Slowdown: New office space deliveries have slowed, with 1.9 million square feet under construction, predominantly in the CBD. About 25% of this space is pre-leased.

9 overlooked ways to earn people‚Äôs trust

postsData.content:
In my view, LLMs will get more accurate with better applications of reinforcement learning, though I think there are diminishing returns to that. However, reliability will always be a fundamental constraint. I like to tease those two apart, because accuracy is task-specific, whereas reliability is about process consistency and maintaining predictable outputs within error tolerances.

DeepSeek made several key innovations:

Ô∏è Using their mixture-of-experts architecture to achieve ChatGPT O1-level reasoning performance through an efficient fine-tuning process.

 Developing a pure reinforcement learning approach for reasoning capabilities without supervised fine-tuning.

‚Äç‚Äç Successfully distilling a 600B+ parameter model down to more practical sizes (as small as 1.5B parameters).

This represents significant progress in efficient model enhancement, though it's important to note that the full development costs, including multiple training runs and data collection, remain substantial. DeepSeek-R1 builds on earlier work while showing how targeted optimization can improve specific capabilities like reasoning tasks.

While developing LLMs from scratch remains extremely expensive, this work demonstrates promising directions for enhancing and specializing existing models more efficiently.

comments.commentText:
You raise an excellent point about the distinction between accuracy and reliability in AI models. As LLMs become more task-specific, refining reliability through consistent processes will be crucial.

Here's why top cold callers set 25-40% of their convos

They have the "X-Factor" meaning they can...

‚Üí read IOIs
‚Üí pick up on tonal cues
‚Üí use situational awareness

This is what separates elite callers from the average ones.

The top cold callers have mastered the art of reading IOIs (Indicators of Interest). They know when a prospect is engaged and interested. This skill allows them to steer the conversation in a way that builds trust and rapport.

Tonal cues are another critical factor. Elite cold callers can pick up on subtle changes in a prospect's tone. They can sense hesitation, excitement, or doubt. This helps them adapt their approach in real-time, making the conversation feel more natural and less scripted.

Situational awareness is the final piece of the puzzle. Top performers are always aware of the context of the conversation. They understand the prospect's industry, pain points, and potential objections. This allows them to provide relevant solutions and build credibility.

postsData.content:
Onboarding a virtual assistant is where most business owners mess up.

They think hiring is the hard part.

It‚Äôs not.

The hard part is teaching someone how to run your business like you do.

Here‚Äôs how to onboard a virtual assistant like a pro:

1. Document everything.
‚Üí Write down your repeatable tasks.
‚Üí Explain them step-by-step, as if you‚Äôre teaching a 10-year-old.
‚Üí Be as specific as possible.

2. Use video.
‚Üí Show them how to do tasks with screen recordings.
‚Üí Tools like Loom are your best friend.
‚Üí Seeing is learning.

3. Start with small wins.
‚Üí Give them one simple task at a time.
‚Üí Set them up for success early.
‚Üí This builds their confidence and your trust in them.

4. Schedule check-ins.
‚Üí Weekly reviews keep everyone aligned.
‚Üí They need feedback, and you need to know they‚Äôre on track.

Onboarding isn‚Äôt just about handing over tasks.

It‚Äôs about creating a partnership.

Invest time upfront, and you‚Äôll get 10x the ROI later.

How you onboard today determines your assistant's success tomorrow.

comments.commentText: This is a solid framework for onboarding a virtual assistant effectively. Many business owners assume hiring is the biggest challenge, but without a structured onboarding process, even the best assistants can struggle.

postsData.content:
Ô∏è The Indian Startup Fund Cycle 

Navigating the Fund Cycle: A Deep Dive into the Journey of an Indian Startup 

‚≠êThe journey of an Indian startup is a dynamic one, marked by distinct phases of growth and funding.

1. Ideation & Seed Stage: It begins with a spark of innovation, followed by meticulous business planning and the crucial search for seed funding from angels, VCs, or even personal networks. This phase focuses on validating the idea, developing a Minimum Viable Product (MVP), and building a strong foundation.
2. Scaling Up with Series A: As traction grows, companies seek Series A funding to accelerate growth, expand operations, and build a robust team. This stage is pivotal for scaling and establishing a strong market presence.
3. Growth & Expansion: Subsequent funding rounds (Series B, C, and beyond) fuel aggressive expansion, market penetration, and product diversification. This phase demands strategic decision-making, navigating competition, and adapting to the evolving market landscape.
4. Exit Strategies: The ultimate goal for many startups is a successful exit, whether through an IPO, acquisition by a larger company, or a buyback by founders.

Ô∏è Key Challenges for Indian Startups:

1. Navigating the Regulatory Landscape: India's diverse regulatory environment presents unique challenges for startups.
2. Talent Acquisition: Accessing and retaining top talent remains a critical hurdle.
3. Infrastructure & Logistics: While improving, India's infrastructure still presents challenges in areas like logistics and supply chain management.
4. Intense Competition: The Indian market is highly competitive, demanding continuous innovation and adaptability.

The fund cycle and its inherent challenges is crucial for the success of any Indian startup. By carefully planning, adapting to the evolving market, and building a strong foundation, Indian companies can navigate the complexities of this journey and achieve sustainable growth. postsData.name:
Ahona Mazumder (she/her)
Ahona Mazumder (she/her)
postsData.content:
OOO: Living a dream!

Now that I'm back to reality, I wanted to share a cool experience I had last weekend. Lightning struck twice and I had the incredible opportunity to sing my favorite Brandi Carlile song with the writers themselves: Brandi Carlile, Tim, and Phil!

I truly don't remember the last time I felt such pure joy! I've been reflecting on this experience and what it means as I re-enter exhausting reality. All that comes to mind is gratitude. I'm re-energized and inspired to be creative inside and outside of work. The reason we had so much fun up on the stage is because it was joy & love given and received - there's no feeling like it. I learned a few lessons from everyone I encountered that day, that I wanted to share; apart from improving my public speaking skills by singing to over 2000 folks...

Brandi, Tim, and Phil (and most touring musicians) make working so hard look so easy. The greatest lesson they teach me is in how they share endlessly. It's a good reminder for me. Sharing your thoughts, your skills, your joy, your time, and then seeing the beautiful community you create when you do is an amazing thing. I often have a hard time speaking up or sharing my creativity in or outside of work, I want to keep remembering to share.

Their crew is a champion of the people. They're excellent listeners, quick on their feet, and the way they can put any performer at ease teaches me that anyone can comfort a stranger and help others succeed. These guys are traveling and working some tough hours and still manage to be the nicest people and want to see you succeed. Supporting your "performers" starts with listening, anticipating, and adjusting.

Everyone who supported us from that stage (and back home) made the whole experience. There's truly no feeling or no place else like GJWW with the amount of love and belonging radiating from everyone, I smiled at every stranger I encountered. It teaches me that all you gotta do is ask to connect. Most people want to share about themselves and love learning something about you.

I'm just so positively overwhelmed; If this is a community that can rise together and hold each other, how do I take that feeling with me into everyday? It'll take conscious effort but it's not hard to be kind, to take a moment to remember what's important, protect your neighbors and coworkers, to share your joy, and hope it brings others along.

Anyway, the most important lesson I learned is to put yourself out there. You never know what may come of it...like meeting your heroes.

postsData.content:
A big failure I've noticed in management from a small business owner is the following; (myself being very guilty). Also, I'll share ideas how I fixed some of this. 

Scenario: Someone is working for you in whatever role. You (Chris / I ) get ideas. I send those in Text, Email, Slack, etc.. and don't provide context. In my mind, it's a "hey, this is an idea we should do sometime, just documenting." BUT, usually how people read it is "Shit... do I do this now? Later? I feel pressure."

Sometimes that pressure builds up and causes issues without me even knowing, however it was my fault.

What I have started doing is reviewing priority lists weekly. I also will document my ideas and go over them at an appropriate time. ALSO, I added in a Tiered system of communications like "R1 = Request lowest level, not urgent" "R2 = Request, somewhat urgent, client or customer." and "R3 = URGENT, client and customer". Possibly R4, doomsday situation.

It's not a perfect system. I'm no master. I am learning and these little things have helped improve workflows with others a lot.

How have you worked on your management or commutation skills?

comments.commentText: We started doing a weekly team member check in sheet via Forms at the end of each week, it's good for feed back and having team members prioritizing and clarifying what they need for the upcoming week. Also we have a weekly 121 meeting each week. We have a running agenda that both of us can add to throughout the week then review on Monday mornings. Cuts down on additional emails and other conversations throughout the week that disrupt day to day work flow

In my experience working with various web and mobile applications, I‚Äôve come to realize that while JWT (JSON Web Tokens) is widely popular, it isn‚Äôt always the best choice. Here‚Äôs why:

Managing JWTs can become tricky, especially as your app scales. Storing and refreshing tokens on different devices and platforms can lead to confusion and errors.

JWTs come with potential vulnerabilities‚Äîif the signing key is compromised, attackers can forge tokens and impersonate users.

JWTs don‚Äôt provide an easy way to manage complex user permissions, making it necessary to implement custom solutions that add unnecessary complexity.

As the number of claims in a JWT grows, the size can become problematic, adding overhead and slowing down network requests.

5. ùóßùóºùó∏ùó≤ùóª ùóòùòÖùóΩùó∂ùóøùòÜ & ùó•ùó≤ùòÉùóºùó∞ùóÆùòÅùó∂ùóºùóª
Once a JWT is issued, you can‚Äôt easily revoke or manage its expiration, complicating security.

As your app grows, scaling JWTs becomes challenging. Multiple servers need synchronized access to valid tokens, which can introduce bugs.

 ùó¢ùóîùòÇùòÅùóµ 2.0: Great for delegating authentication to trusted providers like Google, Facebook, etc. It offers token expiration and revocation management without the complexities of JWT.

 ùó¶ùó≤ùòÄùòÄùó∂ùóºùóª-ùóïùóÆùòÄùó≤ùó± ùóîùòÇùòÅùóµùó≤ùóªùòÅùó∂ùó∞ùóÆùòÅùó∂ùóºùóª: A secure, traditional method that stores session data server-side, making token management easier.

 ùóûùó≤ùòÜùó∞ùóπùóºùóÆùó∏: Open-source identity and access management, perfect for large-scale applications needing centralized authentication and RBAC.
